spanishExample: ¡Cállese! Le dije que necesitaba el cien por ciento.
englishTranslation: (Formal) Shut up! I told you I needed one hundred percent.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")
necesitaba: needed, I needed (Necesitar, imperfect, 1st person)

spanishExample: ¿Temes que si ella pelea perderás?
englishTranslation: Do you fear that if she fights you’ll lose?
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
pelea: fights, he/she/it fights (Pelear, present, 3rd person)
perderás: will , you will lose (Perder, future, 2nd person)
temes: fear, you fear (Temer, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: El sonido es doscientas ochenta y siete veces mejor.
englishTranslation: The sound is two hundred and eighty-seven times better.

spanishExample: No tengo ganas de pelear, sin embargo, quiero que ellos peleen.
englishTranslation: I don’t feel like fighting; however, I want them to fight.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
peleen: fight, they fight (Pelear, subjunctive, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Había cuatrocientas noventa y tres personas ahí y la mayoría hablaba inglés.
englishTranslation: There were four hundred and ninety-three people there and the majority spoke English.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
hablaba: was speaking, he/she/it was speaking (Hablar, imperfect, 3rd person)
había: "there was/were" indicating existence (Haber, imperfect, impersonal)

spanishExample: No quiere que yo tema la política como él la temía.
englishTranslation: He doesn’t want me to fear politics like he feared it.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
tema: fear, I fear (Temer, subjunctive, 1st person)
temía: feared, he/she/it feared (Temer, imperfect, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Te di cientos de ejemplos, más de setecientos setenta y seis.
englishTranslation: I gave you hundreds of examples, more than seven hundred and seventy-six.
vocabIncluded: de used to mean “than” in numerical comparisons
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: No quiero que tema por ese ruido.
englishTranslation: I don’t want her to fear because of that noise.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
tema: fear, he/she/it fear (Temer, subjunctive, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Temía que estuvieran peleando por tantas horas.
englishTranslation: I feared they were fighting for so many hours.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
estuvieran: __, they __ (Estar, past subjunctive, 3rd person plural)
temía: feared, I feared (Temer, imperfect, 1st person)

spanishExample: ¡No pelees! ¡No estás en el estado correcto!
englishTranslation: Don’t fight! You’re not in the right state!

spanishExample: Escuché ese sonido ciento dieciocho veces.
englishTranslation: I heard that sound one hundred and eighteen times.
vocabIncluded: escuché: listened, I listened (Escuchar, preterite, 1st person)

spanishExample: Tu pareja no quiere que pelees.
englishTranslation: Your partner doesn’t want you to fight.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
pelees: fight, you fight (Pelear, subjunctive, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Me dio ciento cincuenta y un dólares para que me calle.
englishTranslation: She gave me one hundred and fifty-one dollars so that I shut up.
vocabIncluded: calle: shut up, I shut up (Callar, subjunctive, 1st person)
me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")

spanishExample: Él nunca se calla y por eso peleas con él.
englishTranslation: He never shuts up and that’s why you fight with him.
vocabIncluded: calla: shuts up, he/she/it shuts up (Callar, present, 3rd person)
peleas: fight, you fight (Pelear, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Esa pareja le dio ochocientos cuarenta y cuatro dólares.
englishTranslation: That couple gave him eight hundred and forty-four dollars.
vocabIncluded: le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: En base a ese ruido, me temo que aún están peleando.
englishTranslation: Based on that noise, I’m afraid they are still fighting.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
temerse: any use of temer with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to be afraid
temo: fear, I fear (Temer, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: Faltan trescientos veintidós dólares.
englishTranslation: Three hundred and twenty-two dollars are missing.
vocabIncluded: faltan: lack/are missing, they lack/are missing (Faltar, present, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: La base estaba en la posición correcta.
englishTranslation: The base was in the right position.

spanishExample: Me temo que la mayoría de las personas en nuestra red no nos ayudarán.
englishTranslation: I’m afraid the majority of the people in our network won’t help us.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
temerse: any use of temer with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to be afraid
temo: fear, I fear (Temer, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: En base a la conversación de cientos de personas, eso no es lo que temen.
englishTranslation: Based on the conversation of hundreds of people, that’s not what they fear.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
temen: fear, they fear (Temer, present, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Nuestra red no es buena, aunque es novecientos sesenta y cinco pesos por mes.
englishTranslation: Our network isn’t good, even though it’s nine hundred and sixty-five pesos per month.
vocabIncluded: peso: weight/peso as in currency (masc. noun)

spanishExample: Él teme que la base no sea buena, sin embargo, sé que es buena.
englishTranslation: He fears the base isn’t good; however, I know it’s good.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
teme: fears, he/she/it fears (Temer, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: No peleamos ayer, pero peleo hoy.
englishTranslation: We didn’t fight yesterday, but I fight today.
vocabIncluded: peleamos: fought, we fought (Pelear, preterite, 1st person plural)
peleo: fight, I fight (Pelear, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: No quiere que tema, aunque faltaban seiscientas treinta personas.
englishTranslation: She doesn’t want me to fear, even though there were six hundred and thirty people missing.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
faltaban: lacked/were missing, they lacked/were missing (Faltar, imperfect, 3rd person plural)
tema: fear, I fear (Temer, subjunctive, 1st person)

spanishExample: Cállense para que yo pueda tener una conversación con ella.
englishTranslation: (Plural) Shut up so I can have a conversation with her.
vocabIncluded: pueda: "be able", "I be able" (Poder, subjunctive, 1st person)

spanishExample: Peleamos por el color y el tamaño.
englishTranslation: We are fighting over the color and the size.
vocabIncluded: peleamos: fight, we fight (Pelear, present, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: ¡Cállate! No te has callado en como quinientas nueve horas.
englishTranslation: Shut up! You haven’t shut up in like five hundred and nine hours.
vocabIncluded: has: "have", "you have" before a participle (Haber, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Puede temer estar en ese estado.
englishTranslation: He might fear being in that state.

spanishExample: Nos tememos que tenemos dudas.
englishTranslation: We’re afraid we have doubts.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
tememos: fear, we fear (Temer, present, 1st person plural)
temerse: any use of temer with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to be afraid

spanishExample: Quiero que él se calle porque él no quiere que yo tema.
englishTranslation: I want him to shut up because he doesn’t want me to fear.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
calle: shut up, he/she/it shut up (Callar, subjunctive, 3rd person)
tema: fear, I fear (Temer, subjunctive, 1st person)

spanishExample: ¡No peleen! Será malo si pelean por política.
englishTranslation: (Plural) Don’t fight! It will be bad if you fight over politics.
vocabIncluded: pelean: fight, they fight (Pelear, present, 3rd person plural)
será: "will be", "he/she/it will be" (Ser, future, 3rd person)

spanishExample: No me puedo callar; tengo ganas de hablar.
englishTranslation: I can’t shut up; I feel like talking.
vocabIncluded: hablar: to speak / to talk (Hablar infinitive)

spanishExample: Cien por ciento de las personas quiere que pelee.
englishTranslation: One hundred percent of the people want me to fight.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
pelee: fight, I fight (Pelear, subjunctive, 1st person)

spanishExample: No puedes callarte, tienes que darme un ejemplo en inglés.
englishTranslation: You can’t shut up, you have to give me an example in English.
vocabIncluded: callarte: to shut up (Callar infinitive) + contraction
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Faltaba color en esa foto.
englishTranslation: There was color missing in that picture.
vocabIncluded: faltaba: lacked/was missing, he/she/it lacked/was missing (Faltar, imperfect, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Quiero que te calles y quiero que ella pelee contigo.
englishTranslation: I want you to shut up and I want her to fight with you.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
calles: shut up, you shut up (Callar, subjunctive, 2nd person)
pelee: fight, he/she/it fight (Pelear, subjunctive, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Falta una duda antes de que podamos terminar.
englishTranslation: There’s a doubt left before we can finish.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
falta: lacks/is missing, he/she/it  lacks/is missing (Faltar, present, 3rd person)
podamos: "be able", "we be able" (Poder, subjunctive, 1st person plural)
